awd_titl_txt: Development and Implementation of ARROWS (Advancement, Recruitment, and Retention of Women in Science)
awd_abstract_narration: The College of Medicine at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) is developing and implementing ARROWS (Advancement, Recruitment, and Retention of Women in Science): a package of practices and policies that will specifically benefit women basic scientists and easily be disseminated to other colleges of medicine (COMs). The goals of the current work are to (1) Increase the number of women basic scientists (including racial/ethnic minority women scientists) recruited into COMs by changing the applicant pool and hiring practices; and (2) Improve the retention & advancement of women scientists (including racial/ethnic minority women scientists) in COMs by achieving the critical mass, changing the promotion practices, and providing key supports. This ADVANCE project is adapting strategies from research and best practices and disseminating the effective package of adaptations at a national level.  It is also addressing the specific barriers faced by women basic scientist faculty. The project work is designed to foster a culture that promotes recruitment, retention, participation, and advancement in a way that is both sustainable and serves as a viable model for peer institutions. Consistent with research on the theory of tokenism, which argues that women experience more discrimination (i.e., inequities) if they are tokens rather than a critical mass, the goal of the ARROWS package is to increase the overall number of women basic scientists employed (through both recruitment and retention) and holding positions of high rank and leadership as a means of achieving critical mass and overcoming the adverse effects associated with women perceiving themselves as tokens in the workplace. Within the framework of the empirically supported Social Ecological Model, multiple layers of influence (i.e., individual scientist, department, college, national network of COMs) that affect engagement and promotion of female and ethnically diverse scientists must be simultaneously targeted to accomplish this goal.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF ADVANCE programs are changing the landscape of academic institutions across the country, leading to greater representation of women in STEM careers. However, this initiative has not yet impacted an important stakeholder—the nation’s medical schools, which employ nearly 30% of women scientists in the academic sector. Our project is the first to address the specific barriers faced by women scientist faculty at Colleges of Medicine. It is designed to foster a culture in our medical school that promotes our recruitment, retention, participation, and advancement in a way that is both sustainable and serves as a viable model for peer institutions (i.e., Colleges of Medicine). As a result of the NSF ADVANCE award, we implemented Advancement, Recruitment, and Retention of Women in Science (ARROWS) with the goal of increasing the number of women and URM in the College of Medicine and improving the retention and advancement of women scientists by achieving the critical mass, changing the promotion practices, and providing key supports.

Due to the breadth of our programs and strategies, our outcomes have been substantial. Our efforts to promote diversity and inclusion and conduct unconscious bias training have been institutionalized by the establishment of a Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Institutional Office and the adoption of Diversity and Inclusion as a strategy for the institutional 2015-2010 Strategic Plan. We implemented language in job postings that make it appealing for women and URM to apply for faculty positions. We established the first professional chapter of SACNAS, and we implemented a quarterly Diversity and Ethnic Relations Coffee Hour. We provided faculty support resources on our website, expanded the number of lactation rooms on our campus. We established three awards: a Fellowship award for a woman to establish a relationship with a career mentor outside our institution, an Advancement of Women Award for a faculty who promotes the careers of women, and an Eminent Scholar award for an external speaker who is a prominent and world renown woman scholar. We developed a yearly Career Development Program focused on promotion, tenure, and leadership development, and an organic Mini-Mentoring program that offers ‘a la carte’ one-on-one brief mentoring sessions. We used impression management strategies in media/publications and posting stories about the women scientists and their accomplishments and honors on our website We implemented an external grant review program that has resulted in improving grant funding success rates for women scientists. We organized workshops on topics relevant to women scientists such as Negotiations, Self-Promotion, Management skills, Grant Writing, Time Management, Sponsors and Mentors, Difficult Conversations, Work Life Balance, among others. We also expanded our outreach via experiential activities for elementary and middle school girls as part of a program we coined #STEMlikeagirl.

In summary, although the ARROWS package was developed in the immediate environment of a single medical school, the practices we implemented and information we disseminated will help other medical colleges recruit, retain, and advance women and URM scientists.
